text: when I wrote uh the book that I did on
AI it came out 25 years ago um it was a
very very different time in the um in in
the discipline and you know I wrote a
book about um a group of grad students
at Berkeley who were uh trying to
program a computer to have common sense
uh and in particular there was uh you
know there was one guy who was you know
who had given his uh computer a problem
which was that the computer uh you know
was uh uh we're anthropomorphizing here
a bit but the computer woke up in the
morning and it looked outside and it saw
that it was raining and it had to decide
to put on a rain coat before it went
outside so really the whole book in a
way was about this guy trying to get his
computer to put on a raincoat um and um
you know with with without great success
um and when of the things that uh uh
interested me about Berkeley Was Not
only was there this uh you know sort of
compelling uh group of students and uh
and a a a faculty adviser who had uh
worked with Roger shank at Yale one of
the leading AI uh researchers um but U
there also a couple of philosophers
there who uh for different reasons took
issue with the whole idea of AI one of
them was uh you know Henry drus um who
argued that uh this approach wasn't
going to work that it was sort of like
um I think the metaphor that he used was
uh you know like building a Stairway To
The Moon um yes it would get you closer
but it wouldn't get you there um and um
that's kind of what's happened this idea
that you can you know uh program a
computer to uh you know have uh to to to
be in situations and to have uh you know
certain types of thoughts that you you
know give it in some you know more or
less Godlike way um uh has really um you
know not panned out and and what is
happening is that uh you know we're
we're beginning to see emergent systems
you know systems where uh you know uh uh
uh computers are you know begin to show
emergent intelligence and um uh that
seems to you know in that work in a way
somewhat resembles the brain and that
they're you know massively parallel uh
processing and you know that sort of
thing um so uh you know that seems to be
a much more you know much more promising
uh uh um uh area and um you know I I
think um I think now you know people
like KW are are forecasting some uh some
some pretty radical developments um you
know we'll we'll see where that goes but
uh uh it certainly um uh it's certainly
a long way from where it was when I was
writing about it
